img.alt: Founder and Principal Dr. Bernida Thompson NBCDI Guardian of the Year 2016

p.span: ALL Roots Public Charter School students are expected to arrive at school daily, wearing the school uniform— NO EXCEPTIONS!! Parents will be called to pick-up their children who are not in uniform.

span.img: We commemorate the birthday of Dr. Frances Cress Welsing. She was born March 18, 1935 and died on Jan. 2, 2016. She was a psychiatrist in Washington, DC who devoted more than thirty years to the study of the origin and institution of racism and white supremacy.

p.span: Dr. Welsing's writings, lectures and ideas have helped many people, including scientists and scholars, understand the worldwide system of white supremacy. Dr. Welsing's scholarly work compiled in her book; The Is papers that are changing the course of history.

span.img: Quincy Delight Jones, Jr. He was born March 14, 1933 in Chicago, Illinois. Quincy Jones has succeeded in almost every segment of the media and entertainment industry.

p.span: In music, he has been nominated for a record 79 Grammy's and has won more than any living musician (27). He has pro- duced the best-selling album of all –time (Michael Jackson’s Thriller) & the best-selling single of all-time (We Are The World). He has produced, composed, conducted, arranged
or performed on more than 400 albums.
In film, he produced The Color Purple which was nominated for 7 Oscars. He is the only African–American producer to be nominated for Best Picture.

Yesterday, (Mar 23), the Roots Public Charter School Board of Directors voted to remain closed through April 24, 2020, as recommended by DCPCSB, OSSE, and the Mayor’s office, also in alignment with DCPS. We will reopen Monday, April 27. All assessments (PARCC, CLASS, etc) have been canceled for the SY 2020.
Teachers, during this time teachers will be expected to keep an open line of communication using email, text messaging, phone calls, class dojo, and video conferencing.

li.span: The Md. Science Center In-camp postponed until later in the school year.
School will be closed through April 24th, with school opening on the 27th.

Students will do remote learning through i-ready assignments in ELA and Math. Teachers can monitor in real-time students progress. Teachers also have phone numbers of students in order to help them by personal instruction and communicate with families to address any concerns.

Students who do not have computers can borrow one from the school. ELA and Math work packets will also be distributed. Teachers will communicate with families through classroom dojo and active phone calls and texts. We encourage those without internet access to sign up for the free Comcast.
The SPED teacher will provide instructional support and have close daily communication with students with disabilities. The SPED teacher can also have virtual meetings using Skype and Facetime.
Students will also receive take-home learning packets.
